Imphal East.title: Imphal East, Manipur
info: One of the two districts that form the Imphal valley.
The district headquarters is at Porompat.
Features the historic Kangla Fort, the ancient capital of Manipur.
The Ima Keithel (Mother's Market), one of the world's largest all-women markets, is partially located here.
Predominantly inhabited by the Meitei people.

Imphal West.title: Imphal West, Manipur
info: Contains the state capital, Imphal.
It is the most populous and developed district in Manipur.
The district headquarters is Lamphelpat.
Home to the Shri Shri Govindajee Temple, a historic Vaishnavite center.
Features the Imphal War Cemetery, commemorating soldiers who died in World War II.

Bishnupur.title: Bishnupur, Manipur
info: Known for the Loktak Lake, the largest freshwater lake in Northeast India.
Home to the Keibul Lamjao National Park, the world's only floating national park and the last natural habitat of the Sangai deer.
The district headquarters is Bishnupur town.
Famous for the 15th-century Vishnu Temple, which showcases ancient architectural styles.
INA Memorial at Moirang commemorates the hoisting of the Indian National Army flag for the first time on Indian soil.

Thoubal.title: Thoubal, Manipur
info: Located in the Imphal valley, it is one of the most fertile districts of Manipur.
The district headquarters is at Thoubal town.
Known for its agricultural productivity, particularly in rice cultivation.
Khongjom War Memorial, located here, commemorates the last battle of Manipuri independence against the British in 1891.
The district is rich in lakes and rivers, making it ideal for pisciculture.

Kakching.title: Kakching, Manipur
info: Carved out of Thoubal district in 2016.
The headquarters, Kakching town, is a major commercial hub for the surrounding areas.
Often referred to as the 'Granary of Manipur' due to its high agricultural output.
The Uyok Ching is a popular local spot featuring a garden and a statue of Ibudhou Panganba.
The district is known for its skilled blacksmiths and handicraft artisans.

Senapati.title: Senapati, Manipur
info: A hill district located in the northern part of Manipur.
Inhabited by various Naga tribes, primarily the Mao, Maram, Poumai, and Thangal.
The district headquarters is Senapati town.
Dzükou Valley, a scenic valley known for its seasonal flowers, is partly located in this district.
It is an important transit point on the Imphal-Dimapur highway (NH-2).

tourist_places.name: Dzükou Valley (Part)
tourist_places.location: Border of Nagaland and Manipur, Senapati, Manipur

Ukhrul.title: Ukhrul, Manipur
info: A hill district in eastern Manipur, bordering Myanmar.
Predominantly inhabited by the Tangkhul Naga tribe.
Known for the Shirui Lily (Lilium mackliniae), a rare and unique lily found only in the Shirui Hills.
The headquarters, Ukhrul town, is the highest hill station in Manipur.
The Khangkhui Mangsor Cave is a famous limestone cave with historical significance.

Churachandpur.title: Churachandpur, Manipur
info: The largest district in Manipur by area.
Predominantly inhabited by various Kuki-Chin-Mizo tribes like the Paite, Hmar, Vaiphei, and Thadou.
The headquarters, Churachandpur town, is the second-largest town in the state.
Khuga Dam is a major multipurpose project providing irrigation and power.
The district is known for its vibrant tribal culture and handlooms.

Tamenglong.title: Tamenglong, Manipur
info: A hill district known for its rich biodiversity and dense forests.
Often called the 'Land of the Hornbill'.
Inhabited by the Zeliangrong Naga community (Zeme, Liangmai, Rongmei).
Famous for its oranges and hosts the state-level Orange Festival.
The Tharon Cave and the Zeilad Lake are major natural attractions.

Chandel.title: Chandel, Manipur
info: Located in the southeastern part of Manipur, bordering Myanmar.
The India-Myanmar border town of Moreh, a major international trade center, is in this district (now Tengnoupal).
The district is inhabited by Anal, Lamkang, Kuki, and other tribes.
The headquarters is at Chandel town.
Known for its rich flora and fauna.

Kangpokpi.title: Kangpokpi, Manipur
info: Carved out of Senapati district in 2016.
The district headquarters is Kangpokpi town.
Inhabited by a diverse mix of communities, including Kukis, Nepalis, and Nagas.
The Koubru mountain is a major pilgrimage site for the Meitei people.
The region is known for its scenic beauty and waterfalls.

Tengnoupal.title: Tengnoupal, Manipur
info: Created in 2016 by bifurcating Chandel district.
Home to Moreh, a bustling commercial town on the India-Myanmar border.
Moreh is a key point for the government's 'Act East' policy.
The district headquarters is at Tengnoupal town.
Inhabited by Kuki, Meitei, Tamil, and other communities.

Kamjong.title: Kamjong, Manipur
info: A new district created in 2016 from Ukhrul district.
The headquarters is at Kamjong town.
It shares an international border with Myanmar.
The region is known for its rugged terrain and scenic beauty.
Predominantly inhabited by the Tangkhul Naga tribe.

Noney.title: Noney, Manipur
info: Carved out of Tamenglong district in 2016.
The headquarters is at Noney town.
The world's tallest railway bridge pier, part of the Jiribam-Imphal railway line, is being constructed here.
The district is rich in natural beauty with numerous waterfalls and caves.
Inhabited mainly by the Rongmei Naga tribe.

Pherzawl.title: Pherzawl, Manipur
info: Created in 2016 from Churachandpur district.
The headquarters is Pherzawl town.
It is a remote district bordering Mizoram and Assam.
Inhabited by Kuki-Chin-Mizo groups, primarily the Hmar tribe.
The Barak River flows through this district.

Jiribam.title: Jiribam, Manipur
info: Upgraded to a district in 2016 from a sub-division of Imphal East.
Often called the 'Western Gate of Manipur' as it borders Assam's Cachar district.
The headquarters, Jiribam town, is a key railway head for the state.
The district has a diverse population of Meiteis, Bengalis, Hmars, and others.
The Jiri River and Barak River flow through the district.
